awd_titl_txt: S&AS: FND: Learning-Enabled Autonomous 3D Exploration for Underwater Robots
awd_abstract_narration:
There are often high costs and safety risks associated with humans performing work underwater, which is frequently required to inspect the health of our subsea infrastructure and environment. This motivates a need for smart and taskable autonomous robots that can monitor and inspect the subsea environment, as well as explore their surroundings when they do not have access to an accurate prior model. Without precise instructions on where and how to explore, the ideal taskable robot should be able to produce comprehensive, accurate maps of its surroundings, make repeated decisions about where to travel next, and ensure that it avoids collisions in the process of doing so. This project will leverage machine learning techniques to produce and deploy new algorithms with the potential to enhance both the speed and efficiency with which underwater robots explore unknown environments, and to enable further gains in performance as the exploring robots gain more experience.

Specifically, this project will introduce machine learning techniques to (1) build more descriptive occupancy maps from the sparse and noisy sonar data that typifies the subsea domain; (2) to save computational effort in the potentially exhaustive evaluation of many candidate sensing actions; and (3) to learn effective behaviors for exploring complex, unstructured environments that truly require three-dimensional spatial reasoning. The real-time, 3D exploration task will be managed in concert with other relevant objectives, such as minimizing localization and map uncertainty, and the time and energy expenditures associated with travel. A related goal is to develop robot systems whose performance improves with experience, dynamically choosing the most effective decision-making tools in its portfolio and self-parameterizing the most appropriate map representations for the task at hand.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE TRUSTEES OF THE STEVENS INSTITUTE OF TECHNOLOGY

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated the ways in which machine learning could be applied to the problem of autonomous exploration of complex three-dimensional environments by underwater robots. This is a compelling application for machine learning due to the poor situational awareness and sparse, noisy sensor data that supports the operation of underwater robots in cluttered environments. The team pursued this research with the goal of producing both a taskable and reflective autonomous underwater vehicle capable of robust navigation and decision making when exploring previously unknown, complex and cluttered environments.

The Intellectual Merits of this project were comprised of novel research on robot perception and decision-making algorithms that focused on two key research thrusts:

1 - Designing new algorithms for instantaneous learning-aided robot perception, where training data was assimilated from a robot's real-time sensor observations during the mission at hand. This was studied in the context of learning-aided mapping to support autonomous exploration of unknown environments. 

2 - Designing novel learning-based perception and decision-making algorithms for autonomous robot exploration, where is a robot is trained extensively in advance (with the support of simulation), to make good decisions that would otherwise result from algorithms and optimization procedures that are not real-time viable on an embedded system.

Our research resulted in five publications on the first thrust, four publications on the second thrust, and five publications on supporting capabilities, such as simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM), and motion planning under uncertainty. 

The Broader Impacts of this project were numerous, and there is potential for more impact to be produced with time as the products of this project are read, utilized, and adapted by others. 

Within this project's principal disciplines, the products of this research are likely to have an impact on how engineers will approach the problem of building predictive maps from sparse range observations, on the design decisions and creation of new system architectures for future sonar-equipped underwater vehicles intended to operate autonomously in cluttered environments, and on how engineers and scientists configure the state estimation, localization, and map-building frameworks of mobile robots operating in GPS-denied environments, especially when the data-efficiency of SLAM is a concern.

It is also expected that scientists and engineers in other disciplines (such as civil/environmental/ocean engineering, petroleum engineering, construction, defense, and security), given evidence of the potential benefits of this research, may plan future efforts that incorporate autonomous underwater vehicles and their navigation capabilities for use in inspection and intervention in complex, three-dimensional subsea environments.

Additionally, the motivations and outcomes of this research were incorporated into the curricula of three courses that the PI teaches at Stevens Insitute of Technology: (1) Design VII, (2) Design VIII, and (3) Autonomous Navigation for Mobile Robots. The lectures delivered in all three of these courses were enhanced by incorporating the motivations and findings of state-of-the-art research addressing the autonomous navigation of mobile robots. 

Over its full duration, this project supported (in whole or in part) the research, training, and education of eight PhD students, all of whom have joined or are interested in joining the U.S. science and engineering workforce upon the completion of their doctoral studies. Finally, the project also supported educational outreach encompassing students who are underrepresented in STEM fields - the outcomes of this research were incorporated into numerous lectures delivered to New York City public high schools by the PI over the course of the project. 


Last Modified: 07/15/2023
Modified by: Brendan Englot
